# Wooden Vessels

### Large-scale Fermentation

For large-scale fermentation, **wooden barrels** make excellent vessels. The barrel used for fermentation, originally acquired from the Jack Daniel’s distillery for $75, was initially used to age whiskey. It has a capacity of around 55 gallons (approximately 200 liters).

### Use for Radish Kraut
- The barrel is employed for fermenting radish kraut, accommodating around 440 pounds (200 kg) of vegetables.
- Initially, the barrel had only a single small hole (called a bung). To make it suitable for fermenting kraut, a tapered wooden bung plug was used, which can be easily crafted or bought.

### Fermentation Process
1. **Setup**: The barrel is used in a manner similar to a crock. After filling it with vegetables:
   - Two semicircular hardwood boards are placed on top of the vegetables.
   - These boards are weighed down with either two jugs of water or a water-filled crock.
   - The entire setup is then covered with a cloth.
2. **Maintenance**: During the winter fermentation period, surface molds may develop. These are removed along with any discolored or mushy vegetables at the exposed edges.
3. **Harvesting**: 
   - The vegetables under the brine remain fine throughout the fermentation.
   - During harvest in the winter and spring, the exposed moist wooden sides of the barrel may completely mold, necessitating cleaning.

### Notes
- Wooden barrels, while prone to hosting microbes, are mostly dominated by lactic acid bacteria from the vegetables, ensuring a protected fermentation environment under the brine.

```markdown
# Vintner’s Choices 
Balanced vs. high yield, pure vs. blended, red vs. rosé

The greatest challenge with Cinsaut, as with Carignan or Grenache, is to keep yields in balance. Winemakers may be tempted to get greedy and allow the vines to put out lots and lots of fruit. Ironically, high yields have minimal effect on the color of the grapes, which is why it’s appealing to let it go. But when the vines produce exuberantly, the fruit becomes increasingly dilute. Its tannins, already relatively low, drop further as yields are extended, lowering the life expectancy of the wine. All of these factors call for blending the grape with other varieties, and it is often cast in a supporting role. It’s known for adding a rustic, fruity, or meaty character to wines, with nuances of pepper (these can be hard to distinguish if it’s blended with Mourvèdre or Syrah) and various spice notes. For the finest examples of Cinsaut as a red wine, seek out South African and Lebanese versions. However, Cinsaut’s fruit character is best shown off in a rosé—especially in Tavel, but also throughout Provence and into the Southwest. As a major component of blush wines, Cinsaut adds flavors of tart berry and cherry fruit with spice and notes of black tea and watermelon. Tavel’s qualities are emulated by many dry rosé wines around the world (with the exception of vin gris wines, specifically the lighter “gray” bleed from Pinot Noir, which are elegant, less weighty, and unquestionably less fruit-driven).

## PAIRING WITH FOOD

Because good red Cinsaut can be hard to find, I focus mostly on rosé styles. As a red, Cinsaut has a meaty and spicy character without the charm and assertive black pepper of Mourvèdre or the overtly grapey charm of Grenache. It pairs best with spicy and ethnic fare, from North African couscous and tagine to rustic stews and daubes or even a hearty bowl of Creole red beans and rice. Although it matches nicely with most grilled meats, a more regal red wine will show off your marbled beef better.

As a rosé with food, Cinsaut rocks. Indulge me while I extol the merits of good, dry blush wines. Most wine consumers do not take rosé seriously. It’s seen as maybe suitable for a picnic or a beach party, but not for the dinner table. These people are missing out. Rosé is loved by winemakers, who appreciate its unique white-wine structure, its light red-wine flavor, and its affinity with food. It’s a great alternative to beer and a change from drinking chewy reds.

Dry rosé is brilliant with seafood of all kinds. If it has a shell or fins, it will go with dry rosé—grilled tilapia or tuna, steamed mussels or clams, salty anchovies or sardines, and sashimi of any color or texture. At the Asian table, a good Tavel pairs beautifully with dim sum, Indian biryani, Japanese yakitori, and Singaporean chicken rice. Dry rosé is also very good with many dishes from the Caribbean, ranging from Jamaican jerk chicken to a good Cuban pressed-pork sandwich or one of those wonderful seafood concoctions from Martinique, Barbados, or Antigua. And if you want a great wine for gumbo or paella, look no further. I could go on and on, but I have to save a few other tablemates for Grenache.
```

### Fruits

#### Fruits Tropicaux

- **Avocat Haas, avocat du Brésil, avocat bacon, avocats cocktail**: Fruit de la zone tropicale, consommés surtout pour leur saveur riche. Originaires du Brésil, ils sont reconnus pour leur diversité et goût unique, surtout utilisés dans des cocktails de fruits.
  
- **Grenade**: En provenance d’Asie du Sud-Ouest jusqu’à l’Himalaya, la grenade est appréciée aussi bien pour son jus que pour sa capacité à agrémenter les plats salés ou sucrés grâce à son équilibre entre douceur et acidité.
  
- **Fruit de la Passion et Grenadilles**: Fruits issus de l’Asie, ils sont très prisés pour leur teneur en nutriments, notamment les antioxydants. La pulpe de ces fruits est extrêmement savoureuse, qu’elle soit consommée raw ou dans des préparations.
  
- **Mangoustan**: Originaire d'Asie du Sud-Est, ce fruit est particulièrement riche en antioxydants, consommé souvent en salades de fruits ou sorbets pour sa fraîcheur et son goût unique.

#### Conseils de Consommation et Preparation
- La consommation de ces fruits tropicaux peut varier selon le type de fruit. Il est conseillé de les consommer mûrs pour profiter pleinement de leurs saveurs. Some appropriate cooking or serving suggestions for these fruits include:
  - **Avocats**: Idéal dans les salades ou comme garnitures grâce à sa saveur riche et crémeuse.
  - **Grenade**: Parfaite pour ajouter une touche de couleur et de saveur antioxydante dans des salades ou des plats principaux.
  - **Fruit de la passion et Grenadilles**: Excellente base pour des boissons ou des desserts légers.
  - **Mangoustan**: Best enjoyed fresh in desserts or salads for a tropical taste.

By understanding the unique flavors and uses of these tropical fruits, consumers can enhance their culinary experiences. These fruits not only add exotic taste to dishes but also offer diverse health benefits due to their rich nutrient content.

### The Land, The Grapes, and The Vineyards

The majority of the vineyards of the Languedoc-Roussillon are planted on a curved plain that forms a giant, sunny semicircle facing the Mediterranean Sea. In so dependably warm a climate, the best wines generally come from vineyards on slopes or on high, cool plateaus along the foothills of the Pyrenees or the Cévennes Mountains. Soils in the region vary from alluvial soils near the sea to chalk, gravel, and limestone farther inland. Some of the best vineyards are filled with round, ancient riverbed stones, similar to those in Châteauneuf-du-Pape.

### Le service des vins au restaurant

**Mise en place (Setup)**
1. **Utiliser un plateau pour le transport du matériel** - Use a tray to transport the equipment.
2. **Adapter la verrerie nécessaire au service du vin** - Adapt the necessary glassware for the wine service.
3. **Retirer la verrerie inutile sur la table du client** - Remove unnecessary glassware from the client's table.
4. **Disposer sur le guéridon (Place on the service cart):**
   - Un verre différent de ceux des clients - A glass different from those of the clients.
   - Une soucoupe pour présenter le bouchon - A saucer to present the cork.
   - Une petite serviette en papier - A small paper napkin.
   - Un dessous de bouteille et une carafe (de type large) - A bottle coaster and a large type decanter.

**Ouverture de la bouteille (Opening the bottle)**
- **Au cours de cette phase, la bouteille ne doit pas tourner!** - During this phase, the bottle must not turn!
- **Poser la bouteille de telle manière qu'elle soit prête à être débouchée sans autre manipulation** - Place the bottle so that it is ready to be uncorked without further handling.
- **Couper proprement la capsule sous la bague, avec le couteau sommelier** - Cut the capsule neatly under the ring with the sommelier knife.
- **Essuyer le goulot de la bouteille avec la serviette** - Wipe the bottle's neck with the napkin.
- **Centrer la vrille, piquer et visser sans transpercer le miroir du bouchon** - Center the spiral, pierce and screw without piercing the cork's mirror.
- **Retirer le bouchon délicatement, sans faire de bruit, le contrôler en le sentant discrètement et le poser sur la soucoupe** - Remove the cork gently, without making noise, control it by discreetly feeling it and place it on the saucer.
- **Essuyer le goulot à nouveau.** - Wipe the neck again.

**Aération du vin (Aeration of the wine)**
- **Le support et la bouteille doivent toujours rester en position horizontale entre le service de chaque client.** - The support and the bottle must always remain in a horizontal position between serving each client.

Here's the structured content from the document titled "FLAVORINGS FROM PLANTS":

---
**Page**: 426 

**Title**: FLAVORINGS FROM PLANTS

### Ginger Usage Across the World
- **Fresh Ginger**: Predominantly used fresh in Asia and parts of the world, including the United States. The main production comes from Hawaii with the harvest season from December to June.
- **Enzymatic Action**: Fresh ginger contains a protein-digesting enzyme problematic in gelatin-based dishes.

### Ginger Aromas
- **Flavor Range**: Used for flavoring sausages, fish dishes, as well as sodas and sweets. 
- **Aroma Characteristics**: Combines notes of lemon, fresh, floral, citrus, woody, and eucalyptus with a mild, pepper-like pungency.
- **Geographical Variations**: 
  - Chinese ginger is mainly pungent,
  - South Indian and Australian gingers are citral and lemony,
  - African ginger is delicate and sweet but penetrating.

### Ginger Pungency
- **Variable Pungency**: Ginger pungency varies widely based on its chemical components similar to capsaicin and black pepper’s piperine found in gingerols and shogaols.
- **Effects of Processing**: Drying ginger reduces its pungency by transforming gingerols to shogaols, which are milder when dried. Cooking reduces pungency further by converting some gingerols and shogaols to zingerone, which has a slightly pungent and sweet-spicy aroma.

### Rare Spices
- **Grains of Paradise**: Known also as guinea grains, alligator pepper, and melegueta pepper, these are names for Aframomum melegueta. Originating from West Africa, widely used in the Middle Ages but rare by the 19th century.

### Mace and Nutmeg
- **Origin and Botany**: Both spices are from the fruit of the tropical Asian tree, Myristica fragrans, originating in New Guinea and prevalent in the Spice Islands.
- **Historical Usage**: Gained prominence with European sea powers and Dutch monopolization until nutmeg was successfully planted in the Caribbean and elsewhere.
- **Culinary Uses**: Essential flavoring in doughnuts, eggnog, and used in sausages as well as classic French Béchamel sauce.
- **Mace Characteristics**: Contains stronger flavor notes that are camphorous, woody, warm, somewhat peppery mystiricin, contrasting with the nutty, sweet flavors of nutmeg.

### Nutmeg
- **Seed and Aril**: Nutmeg comes from the seed inside the plum-to peach-sized fruits; mace is the aril wrapping the seed, both processed separately.
- **Flavor Components**: Nutmeg’s rich aroma is concentrated in oil-containing tissue of the seed, which includes starch and fatty storages, carrying nutmeg's main flavors and tannins.

Both mace and nutmeg share some underlying taste profiles but mace provides a sharper, more defined flavor profile compared to the broad, blending taste of nutmeg which also includes astringent tannins.

### Title: Paner à l'anglaise
**Subtitle:** Une technique simple pour rendre croustillante toutes les préparations et ainsi faire de délicieuses croquettes.

### Ingredients:
- Farine
- Blanc d'œuf
- Chapelure
- Huile de friture

### Instructions:
1. **Preparation Step 1:**
   - Placez la farine dans une assiette creuse, le blanc d'œuf dans une autre et la chapelure dans une troisième (1).
   - Battez légèrement ou le les blancs d'œufs (selon la quantité à paner) à la fourchette pour les liquéfier sans les faire mousser.

2. **Preparation Step 2:**
   - Passez successivement dans les trois assiettes la préparation à paner: la farine, puis le blanc d'œuf et enfin la chapelure (2).
   - Faites dorer la préparation panée dans l'huile chaude (3) et goûtez sur du papier absorbant.

3. **Cooking and Storing:**
   - Si les croquettes ne sont pas consommées immédiatement, réservez-les au chaud dans un four préchauffé à 100°C (th. 3/4).

### Chef's Tips:
- **Le conseil du chef:**
  - L'élément à paner doit être bien sec : c'est pour cela qu'on le roule dans la farine, afin que l'ensemble soit croustillant.
  - Si vous panez des ingrédients très humides, comme du tofu, veillez à bien le presser et le sécher (voir technique, p. 88).

### Additional Info:
- **Bon à savoir:**
  - Pour les préparations assez riches en eau et par conséquent de texture très souples, comme celles à base de purée de légumes ou de pommes de terre, placez-les au réfrigérateur au moins 1 heure, voire au congélateur. On peut paner facilement une préparation surgelée, mais sa cuisson sera plus longue.

### Related Recipes:
- Croquettes à la dulse et salade d'asperges crues, p. 343
- Saucisses de Glamorgan, p. 267

The text and content from the document discusses "Atoms, Molecules, and Chemical Bonds," and primarily focuses on how these chemical bonds influence molecular interactions, particularly through the example of ionic and covalent bonds. Here is a structured breakdown of the document's content:

### ATOMS, MOLECULES, AND CHEMICAL BONDS

#### Key Concepts

**1. Role of Oxygen in Chemical Reactions:**
   - Oxygen is highlighted as a significant electron-grabbing element essential in chemical reactions.
   - The process termed as **oxidation** is vital in reactions where elements like oxygen grab electrons from other compounds (e.g., carbon-hydrogen chains in fats, oils, and aroma molecules).
   - Oxidation leads to a sequence of further reactions, potentially decomposing large molecules into smaller fragments.

**2. Prevention of Oxidation:**
   - Certain antioxidant substances like phenolic compounds (found in plants) help prevent the breakdown of fat molecules by oxygen by giving oxygen the electrons it demands, thus stopping further reaction cascades.

#### ELECTRICAL IMBALANCE AND CHEMICAL BONDS

**1. Chemical Bonding:**
  - An interaction between atoms or molecules due to electron affinity, termed as **chemical bond**.
  - The term refers generally to any force or interaction keeping atoms or molecules bonded.

**2. Ionic Bonds:**
   - Defined by the transfer of electrons between atoms with different electronegativity, resulting in oppositely charged ions.
   - Example used: Sodium (Na) and Chloride (Cl) in sodium chloride (table salt), where sodium ions are positively charged and chloride ions are negatively charged, structured alternately in a solid lattice.
   - **Ionic bonds** are mostly encountered in substances that dissolve in water or other solvents, where they dissociate into charged ions.

**3. Origin of the Term 'Ionic':** 
   - The term **ionic** was originated from the work of Michael Faraday, who used the Greek term for "going" in the context of charged particles moving within an electrical field.

#### Illustration:
- The document contains illustrations of ionic and covalent bonds.
   - **Ionic Bond Illustration:** Shows an atom capturing an electron from another, leading to both atoms becoming ionically charged and held by the attractive force between different charges.
   - **Covalent Bond Illustration:** Displays atoms sharing electrons, resulting in a stable molecular formation.

These elements combine to give a detailed view on the interactions at a molecular level which are pivotal in understanding chemical processes, especially those related to everyday phenomena like cooking and preserving food.

### PAIRING AT HOME: TIPS AND MENUS

Here's a short checklist of points that will enhance your wine and food experiences at home. While some are gathered from the text, others are either common sense or lessons learned from my own experience.

**Decide your priority.** If it’s wine, select the wine or wines you intend to serve, either from your cellar or your local wine shop, and then plan the menu. If you have a special recipe you want to serve, or a specific cuisine or ingredient you want to highlight, be aware that these will, in part, dictate your wine selection(s). Think ahead about what wine will best complement your menu; don’t play Russian roulette or leave things to total chance!

**Make sure your wines are in optimum condition.** When serving an older red wine, stand it up (if possible the day before) and let the sediment settle before decanting. When serving a young red wine, open it and let it breathe (and open up)—a good twenty to forty-five minutes before you plan to eat. For white wines or bubblies, ensure that they are chilled but not cold, and if necessary, pull them out of the refrigerator and let them warm up so you don’t lose the flavor nuances.

**When grocery shopping, choose the best ingredients.** Buy seasonally, and buy what’s best. Don’t set your heart on fresh tomatoes in early spring or winter squash in the middle of summer. I usually start by choosing my fruit and vegetables and then visit the butcher or fishmonger once I’ve thought about what role the produce will play in the meal.

**Less is more.** Let a few stellar seasonal ingredients lead the meal; don’t force it full of complex and possibly conflicting tastes.

**Always have a nice selection of breads and cheeses.** If Pinot Meunier is a winemaker's spackle, bread and cheese are the culinary equivalents, helping to fill any gaps of flavor and texture in a menu.

**Prepare as much in advance as you can.** I have spent many an evening in the kitchen instead of with my guests because I waited till the last minute or simply planned a menu that was too complex. Try to get the table set early and have lots of noshing foods so you can appease the hungry! Remember, it’s ultimately just wine and food; enjoying time with friends and family should take precedence.

The document is a discussion on the subjective terms defining the sweetness of wines and the concepts of "Dryness" and "Sweetness" in wines.

---

**Title: HOW SWEET IT IS (OR ISN’T)**

**Introduction:**
- The document starts by addressing the lack of consistent definitions internationally and nationally for terms like dry, off-dry, medium dry, medium sweet, etc., in the wine industry.
- In 2003, the European Union set regulations that classify wine sweetness based on the wine's acidity and residual sugar levels. A wine can have up to 0.9 percent residual sugar and still be considered “dry” under these terms.

**Definitions by Sweet and Fortified Wine Association:**
- **DRY:** Less than .5 percent residual sugar
- **OFF-DRY:** .5 percent to 1.9 percent residual sugar
- **SEMISWEET:** 2 percent to 6 percent residual sugar
- **SWEET:** More than 6 percent residual sugar
- Note: The document specifies that most chardonnays in the U.S., based on these definitions, would likely be labeled "off-dry."

**Discussion on Dryness and Sweetness:**
- The term "dry" in the context of wines is clarified as not referring to the tactile dryness (as opposed to wet), but to a lack of sugar content that could potentially be fermented into alcohol. It mentions that dryness in wine doesn't necessarily equate to a lack of sweetness since wines can have residual sugars even after fermentation.
- The misconception that dry wines cannot be sweet is addressed; it's noted that even "dry" wines like some Californian chardonnays may contain small amounts of residual sugar, contributing to a mellow taste.
- It’s highlighted that the presence or absence of sweetness in alcoholic beverages is a subject unique to wines as compared to other beverages like colas, which have significant sweetness (around 11 percent residual sugar).

**Insights:**
- The document underscores the complexity and subjective nature of classifying wines based on sweetness and the challenge wine drinkers have in discerning low levels of residual sugar in wine.
- It concludes with a comparative note, implying that the expectation for sweetness in wines significantly differs from that in other types of beverages such as colas.

This explanation combines the key points presented in the document, offering insights into the definitions and perceptions associated with wine sweetness terms.

The document you provided is a section of a textbook or reference related to "Sugars, Chocolate, and Confectionery," focusing specifically on the methods for tempering chocolate. Here is a structured outline of the content provided:

### Document Title:
**SUGARS, CHOCOLATE, AND CONFECTIONERY**

### Section Covered:
**Tempering Chocolate**

### Content Summary:

1. **Introduction to Tempering:**
   - Explanation of the necessity of tempering chocolate by using thermometer and gentle heat.
   - Points out that the process allows the formation of stable crystals, preventing the unstable crystals from forming.

2. **Methods of Tempering Chocolate:**
   - **From Scratch Method:**
     - Heat chocolate to 120°F/50°C to melt all crystals.
     - Cool it to around 105°F/40°C.
     - Continue to stir as it cools to thickens, indicating crystal formation.
     - Portion of the mixture is spread on a cool surface and scraped to mix until it thickens.
     - The thickened chocolate is returned to the bowl and mixed at the precise tempering range of 88–90°F/31–32°C, ensuring melting of any unstable crystals.
   
   - **Reserve Method:**
     - Chop and hold a portion of chocolate tempered with stable crystals.
     - Melt it to 120°F/50°C and then cool it to just above the range where stable crystals form (95–100°F/35–38°C).
     - Stir in the solid portion with its stable crystals, ensuring incorporation during the tempering phase.

3. **General Consideration for Tempered Chocolate:**
   - Maintaining the chocolate in the tempering range until use to prevent premature solidification and uneven consistency. 

4. **Melting Tempered Chocolate While Maintaining Temper:**
   - Discusses the possibility of utilizing tempered melted chocolate without actually tempering during the process, which is a common scenario for manufactured chocolates.

### Graph Description:
- Shows two tempering processes visually on a temperature vs. time graph.
- Solid line indicates a method starting with heating followed by precipitation of stable crystals and maintenance near use temperature.
- Dotted line illustrates allowing chocolate to cool below stable-crystal temperature, form a mixture of crystals, and then warming it to melt unstable crystals but retain stable ones.

### Closings:
- The overall content systematically explains how to properly prepare chocolate for various uses in confectionery through tempering, and the illustration supplements the textual information by showing theoretical temperature control during the process.

### Sugars, Chocolate, and Confectionery

---

#### Advances in Confectionery
In the 15th and 16th centuries, confectionery became an art, focusing on sophistication in design and preparation. Techniques involved pulling molten sugar into delicate threads to create glossy surface decorations. By the 17th century, advancements allowed court confectioners to create elaborate table settings using various sugar hard candy forms, integrating systematic approaches for different types of confections, precursors to today's sugar craft methods.

---

#### A Pleasure for All
By the 18th century, sugar became widely accessible, and entire cookbooks were dedicated to confectionery. England developed a robust sugar habit through tea and jams, becoming staples for the working class.

---

#### Sugar Consumption and Modern Candy
From 1700 to 1780, the per capita sugar consumption increased from 4 pounds/2 kg to 12 pounds/5 kg annually. Developments in the 19th century included machines for sugar refining and mass production, fostering inexpensive candy availability. Innovations like taffy, nougat, and fondant emerged, making candy like bonbons, taffy, and fondant common.
  
---

#### The Rise of the Sugar Industry
The sugar industry boom in the 18th century influenced global trade and colonization, notably in the West Indies. Columbus introduced sugarcane to Hispaniola on his second voyage, significantly impacting the local economics and populations due to increased demand and labor needs.

---

#### Sugar as Disguise
Expressions from confectionery's medicinal origins persist today, reflecting both praise and deceit. The phrase, "sugar over something," implies masking unpleasant realities, an idea that dates back to early medicinal uses of sugar to coat harsh tastes. Shakespeare notably used a metaphoric sugar reference in "Hamlet," highlighting its dual connotations of sweetness and disguise.

```markdown
# Txakoli (cha-koh-lee)

In public speaking, you’re advised never to start off your presentation with an apology. Nevertheless, I am sorry. I am sorry that I have made the decision to present the grape Hondarribi Zuri in this book not by the name of the grape but rather by the Basque name of the far better-known wine made from it, Txakoli. The reason is simple: the name Hondarribi Zuri is unlikely to appear on any wine labels, front or back. If you don’t want blank looks from a store clerk, ask for Txakoli.

Including this wine here, as with Assyrtiko, is a bit of a stretch. Many other wines discussed in *Daring Pairings* are far more widely available and established. And I don’t suspect that we’ll be seeing Txakoli explode in popularity any time soon. However, I passionately believe that this wine has the potential to excel in the United States, and not just because it sounds so good rolling off your tongue. It goes really well with food. Read on.

## Alternative Names
- Chacoli, Txakolina (Basque region, Spain)

## Styles
- Light-bodied dry white
- Light-bodied dry frizzante white

## Sometimes Blended With
- Folle Blanche
- Gros Manseng
- Hondarribi Beltza
- Petit Courbu
- Petit Manseng (All from the Basque region, Spain)

## Flavor Lexicon
- **Fruit**: Citrus (lemon, lime), green papaya, jackfruit
- **Earth**: Mineral

## Similar Sips
- Young Albariño
- Italian Pinot Grigio
- Vinho Verde

## Where It's Grown
- Basque region: Getariako Txakolina, Bizkaiko Txakolina, Arabako Txakolina

## Additional Notes
The Hondarribi Zuri grape, responsible for close to 80 percent of all Txakoli wines, and its kissing cousin, the red Hondarribi Beltza, are both native to the Spanish Basque country. Known best for its unique language, extraordinary food, and the amazing Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, the Basque region sits in the northeast of Spain, along the Bay of Biscay.
```

   - Initially thought of as a local wine for local consumption with food but has gained appreciation among winemakers who produce more serious varieties.
   - Introduced to other regions like California by Italian immigrants, where it is now a central part of the viticulture, particularly noted for its quality improvements and balance in wine making.

### Chapter 44: UNDERSTANDING WINES: EXPLAINING STYLE AND QUALITY

#### Port
Ports are made by adding grape spirit to a fermenting juice to create an alcoholic sweet wine. This technique has been used in this region since the eighteenth century and it is now used to make wines of a similar style throughout the world. Port is made in red, white, and rosé styles but in this chapter, we will focus on red Port.

#### LOCATIONS
The activities of the Port industry are divided between the twin coastal cities of Porto and Vila Nova de Gaia (which lie on opposite sides of the mouth of the river Douro) and the vineyard area that starts 70 kilometers upstream of these towns. These two areas are distinctly different and will be considered separately.

##### IN THE VINEYARD
The vineyards area is divided into three sub-regions. The Baixo Corgo produces the lightest wines; the Cima Corgo is where the greatest number of the top vineyards are found; and the Douro Superior which, although still relatively sparsely planted, is also renowned as a source of top-quality wine.

###### Climate
Broadly speaking, the vineyard area has a warm continental climate as a result of being shielded from the cooling rain-bearing Atlantic winds by the Serra do Marão. However, the climate is not uniform. The Baixo Corgo in the west is the coolest and wettest of the sub-regions. The vineyards become progressively hotter and dryer the further east they are located. Growers have to contend with frosts in spring and heavy downpours on, on occasion, disrupt flowering as well as harvest. In the summer, daytime temperatures can be very high and rainfall throughout the growing season is very low. Viticulture is possible thanks to the schist bedrock, which fractures vertically allowing the vines’ roots to access deep water reserves that are built up by the winter rains.

###### Topography
The vineyards in the Baixo and Cima Corgo are planted on the very tall and very steep slopes that rise up from the banks of the Douro and its tributaries. The topography is varied and this can be exploited by the growers. For example, there can be clear temperature differences between the top and the bottom of a slope.

#### VINEYARD DESIGN IN THE DOURO
1. **Socalcos.** The retaining walls and the lack of easy access are clear to see.
2. **Patamares.** There are no retaining walls and each individual terrace can be accessed by road.
3. **Vinhas ao alto.** The vines are planted in line with the slope. This cannot be used on the steepest slopes. Only the vineyards at the bottom of this photo are planted in this way.

The document contains several sections with structured and unstructured information related to food pairings and aromatic compounds produced during cooking. Below are the details organized into structured formats:

### Classic pairing: bacon and green lentils
- **Description**: Cooking green lentils with pan-fried bacon enhances the meaty flavors found in these legumes. Adding stewed onion, leek and diced fresh tomatoes makes this dish even more savory and juicy.

### Potential pairing: bacon and dark chocolate
- **Description**: The roasted notes found in bacon make a perfect aromatic link to dark chocolate—especially 3-methylbutanol, which has a chocolatey scent. Try crumbling crispy oven-cooked bacon over chocolate mousse.

### Aroma compounds produced during cooking
- **Description**: Whether grilling steak or roasting a chicken, the process results in the formation of the same aroma molecules—just at different rates and in varying concentrations.
  - **Furanols, furanes**: sweet, burnt, fruity, nut, caramellic
  - **Furanones, furanols roasted**: caramellic, sweet, fruity, bread, popcorn
  - **Alpha-dicarbonyls**: butter, burnt
  - **Thiophenes**: roasted, onion or meaty
  - **Thiophenones**: popcorn, nutty
  - **Furanthiols**: burnt, sulphurous or meaty
  - **Other sulphurous compounds**: meaty, onion
  - **Aldehydes**: green, fatty, fruity
  - **Pyrazines, nutty**: roasted, earthy, potato, popcorn, green
  - **Oxazolines, oxazoles woody, musty, green, nutty, sweet, vegetal**: vegetal, meaty, bread, nutty
  - **Thiazolines, thiazoles**: green, vegetal, meat, bread
  - **Pyroles, pyrrolidines, pyridines**: green, sweet, nutty

### Aroma compounds produced during curing bacon
- **Description**: The process of curing bacon not only alters the texture of the pork, but also its aroma profile. Bacon contains nitrites, chemicals used to salt-cure meats. Interaction with other flavor precursors during the curing process causes the formation of nitrosamines that give bacon and other cured meats their characteristic flavor.

### Pan-fried bacon aroma profile
- **Description**: Pan-frying bacon triggers a series of chemical reactions that occur between the lean and fatty tissues, resulting in a fragrant release of aroma molecules.

### Smoked chicken with apple & broad beans: Foodpairing recipe
- **Ingredients**:
  - Chicken
  - Granny Smith apple
  - Fava bean
  - Grape wine
  - Quinoa
- **Description**: Smoked chicken breast is paired with broad bean puree and slices of crisp Granny Smith apple. The chicken is marinated overnight in white wine and olive oil with lemon juice and rosemary, then smoked on the grill, using grapevine wood chips for the nutty mix of woody, phenolic and green-fatty notes they impart. Serve the chicken breast with a sprinkling of puffed quinoa to add a pleasant crunchy, toasted flavor.

The content of the document focuses on the natural history, habitats, and behavior of the yeast species *Saccharomyces cerevisiae*. Here's the structured analysis of the content provided:

1. **Natural Habitat and Association**
    - *S. cerevisiae* is commonly associated with plants, fruits, leaves, flowers, and sap.
    - There is a noted seasonal variation in its population, peaking in the summer.

2. **Vectors and Distribution**
    - Insects play a significant role in dispersing this yeast in nature, as noted by researchers Phaff, Miller, and Mrak.

3. **Debate on Origins**
    - The origins of *S. cerevisiae* are debated:
        - Some researchers believe it evolved solely through human activities and is not found independently in nature.
        - Others, like Ann Vaughan-Martini and Alessandro Martini, argue based on extensive surveys, that it does have a natural origin.
        
4. **Diverse Natural Occurrences**
    - Contrary findings highlight *S. cerevisiae*'s presence in diverse environments such as in mushrooms, oak-tree soils, and beetle guts.
    - Research into beetle digestive tracts identified over 650 distinct yeasts, including *S. cerevisiae*.
    - Gene sequence analysis suggests these yeasts have origins in natural habitats not necessarily linked to alcohol production.

5. **Alcohol Production and Tolerance**
    - Alcohol-producing yeasts, including *S. cerevisiae*, vary in their alcohol tolerance.
        - Some can produce up to about 20% alcohol.
        - Others can only tolerate up to about 3.5% alcohol.
        - Most yeasts function between these extremes.

6. **Focus of the Document**
    - The document focuses on emphasizing wild fermentations that use naturally occurring yeasts, presenting it as a simple, effective, and traditional method.

The document is a detailed exposition on "Flavorings from Plants," focusing particularly on vanilla. It consists of several sections detailing various aspects of vanilla flavor, its processing, and uses. Below is a structured summary of the main points discussed in the text:

### Flavorings from Plants

#### 1. Processing of Vanilla
- **Browning Reactions:** The text describes how vanilla generates pigments and complex aromas via browning reactions between sugars and amino acids.
- **Quantity Conversion:** It takes 3 to 5 pounds of fresh pods to produce 1 pound of cured beans.
- **Curing Process:** Pods are dried and aged over several weeks to develop flavor, which can last several months, especially highlighted in Madagascar's 35–40 day curing process.

#### 2. The Flavors of Vanilla
- **Composition:** The cured pod contains about 20% water, 20% fiber, 25% sugars, 15% fat, with the rest being amino acids, phenolic compounds, and other flavors.
- **Aroma Profiles:** Over 200 different volatile compounds contribute to vanilla's aroma, with vanillin being the principal compound but not solely responsible for the spice’s richness. Descriptions include woody, floral, green-leaf, clove-like, and others.

#### 3. Kinds of Vanilla
- **Regional Varieties:** Different vanilla-producing regions provide beans with varying flavors. Examples include:
  - **Bourbon Vanilla:** From Madagascar, known for rich and balanced flavor.
  - **Indonesian Beans:** Lighter, with less vanillin, smoky qualities.
  - **Mexican Vanilla:** Distinctive fruity and perfumed notes.
  - **Tahitian Vanilla (V. tahitensis):** Less vanillin than Bourbon but has unique flowery notes.

#### 4. Vanilla Extracts and Flavorings
- **Preparation:** Made by chopping vanilla beans, mixing with alcohol and water, and aging the extract to develop complex flavors.
- **Artificial Vanilla:** Derived from synthetic vanillin and lignin by-products, not fully matching the subtle flavors of natural vanilla.
- **Consumption Stats:** About 90% of vanilla flavoring in the U.S. is synthetic, compared to about 50% in France.

#### 5. The Virtues of Vanillin
- **Uses in Cooking:** Vanillin flavor contributes to various foods like smoked meats, whiskeys, bread, and more.
- **Biological Properties:** Vanillin has antimicrobial and antioxidant properties, along with inhibiting DNA damage.

This document efficiently encapsulates the intricate details of vanilla’s flavor profile, processing techniques, and its biological and culinary importance.

The document is about the pairing of wines with food, focusing on the impact of acidity and sweetness on food pairing. Here is the structured content broken down into two key components discussed in the text:

### Key 1: Acidity in Wine

- **Role of Acidity:** 
  - Enhances the flavors of certain foods, particularly where there is a need to counterbalance richness or to complement brininess.
  - Acidic wines are recommended as prime candidates for pairing with creamy or butter-based sauces, strong-tasting fish or shellfish, and mildly piquant dishes.

- **Best Pairings:**
  - Green salads dressed with vinaigrette, dishes with sharp ingredients like capers, leeks, and tomatoes are harmonized well with acidic wines like Assyrtiko, Txakoli, and some Pinot Blancs.

- **Effects on Food Perception:**
  - Lessen the perception of salt.
  - Cut through fatty and rich dishes enhancing overall dish taste.

- **Particular Dish Recommendations:**
  - A refreshingly acidic wine can be a foil for dishes like deep-fried Italian fritto misto or shrimp tempura.
  - Counterintuitively, lower-acid wines might be preferable with dishes that have a slight sharpness themselves like those with a squeeze of lime or lemon. Recommended wines for such pairings include Trebbiano or Marsanne.

### Key 2: Sweetness in Wine

- **General Characteristics:**
  - Varies widely across different wines.
  - Dessert wines are handled on a case-by-case basis.

- **Sweetness Levels:**
  - Wines can be dry (no noticeable sugar), off-dry (slightly sweet), or semi-dry (moderately sweet).
  - Examples of slightly sweet wines include Prosecco, Chenin Blanc, lighter-style Muscats, and some Torrontés.

The document emphasizes that both acidity and sweetness have substantial roles in how wine complements or contrasts food flavors, suggesting a dynamic approach to wine pairing based on these characteristics. The document titled "UNDERSTANDING WINES: EXPLAINING STYLE AND QUALITY" provides an overview of different wine regions in Portugal, discussing the specific characteristics of wines produced in each region as well as geographical details. Below is the structured content extracted from the document, segmented by each wine region featured.

### Dão
- **Location**: Mountainous area 80 kilometers south of the Douro region.
- **Geography**: Vineyards on gentle hills and slopes; elevation between 200 and 400 meters above sea level.
- **Climate**: Cold winters, warm summers, significant temperature variation between day and night.
- **Wine Styles and Grapes**:
  - **Red Wines**: Delicate red fruit aromas, soft tannins, high acidity; improvements with new plantings of Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Jaen (Mencia in Spain), and Alfrocheiro.
  - **White Wines**: Made from Encruzado with styles ranging from light and fresh to richer, barrel-fermented versions.
  - **Flavour Profiles**: Blackberry, strawberry on reds; intense aromas.

### Bairrada
- **Location**: Between Dão and the Atlantic Ocean.
- **Climate**: Maritime; rainy winters and summers.
- **Major Grape**: Baga (dominant, late-ripening variety).
- **Challenges**: Late ripening is problematic.
- **Wine Styles and Techniques**:
  - **Red Wines**: High acidity and astringent tannins early on but softer and tastier with aging.
  - **Techniques**: Blending with other varieties and maceration techniques to improve softness and black fruit flavors.
- **Other Varieties**: Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro; international varieties like Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot.
- **White Wines**: Mainly from indigenous varieties Bical and Maria Gomes.

### Douro
- **Location**: 80 kilometers east of Porto, from Marão Mountains to the frontier with Spain.
- **Historical Note**: The oldest demarcated wine region in the world.
- **Dominant Wine Style**: Port (fortified wines) using grapes Touriga Nacional, Touriga Franca, Tinta Roriz (Tempranillo), Tinta Barroca, Tinta Cão.
- **Unfortified Wines**: High-quality, noted for colour and flavours of deep dark fruits.
- **Notable**: Touriga Nacional produces high-quality wines known for deep colors and intense flavours.
- **White Wines**: From high-altitude vineyards, showing versatility from fruity and medium to high acidity.

### Alentejo
- **Location**: Over eight sub-regions in the south and east of Portugal.
- **Climate**: Growing season is warm, varying from cooler, wetter north to hotter, drier centre and south.
- **Wine Styles**:
  - **Red Wines**: Made with Aragonês (Tempranillo) and Trincadeira, featuring spicy red berry flavors.
  - **White Wines**: Made from Antão Vaz and Roupeiro; feature fruity and aromatic profiles with medium to high acidity.

The document contains tips and troubleshooting advice for making and fermenting shrubs or similar beverages. It highlights common issues that may arise during the fermentation process and provides solutions. Here’s a structured breakdown of the content:

---

**Additional Tips:**
- Consider adding herbs such as mint or other flavoring agents to the vinegar.
- You can use honey or other sweeteners; avoid the cooking step if using raw homemade vinegar.
- For a fizzy drink, dilute with carbonated water.

**Troubleshooting:**

1. **Doesn’t start to ferment:**
   - **Possible Issues:**
     - Non-viable starter.
     - Solution introduced to a too hot environment.
     - Cold ambient temperatures.
     - Use of chlorinated water which inhibits fermentation.
     - Ginger was irradiated if using a ginger bug.
   - **Solutions:**  
     - Check starter viability.
     - Find a warmer environment.
     - Use organic ginger or non-chlorinated water.
     - Keep stirring and be patient.

2. **Gets too sour:**
   - **Issue:** Over-fermentation.
   - **Solution:**
     - Shorten the fermentation time.
     - Use overly soured beverage as vinegar.
     - Dilute with water or carbonated water and sweeten if needed.

3. **Too weak:**
   - **Solution:** Increase the amount of flavoring agent (such as ginger, tea, or fruit) and/or add more sugar.

--- 

These structured sections provide a comprehensive guide for resolving common fermentation issues.

### Rice Flake Crusted Salmon with Chile Citrus Sauce

**Introduction:**
Citrus is a significant ingredient for achieving a strong concentrated flavor without the need for fat. It brings floral notes, fruitiness, and mild heat to dishes. Ginger is highlighted as an essential ingredient that bridges various flavor elements, enhancing dishes with its aromatic character. The citrus sauce is particularly recommended for fish dishes like flounder, halibut, or striped bass.

**Serves:**
4

**Ingredients for Sauce:**
- 2½ cups fresh-squeezed orange juice, strained
- 1/3 cup mirin (sweet rice wine available in Asian markets)
- 1 stalk lemongrass, sliced and very finely chopped
- 2 tablespoons peeled chopped fresh ginger
- 1 dried hot chili
- Kosher salt
- 1 tablespoon sugar

**Preparation Method:**
1. Combine the orange juice, mirin, lemongrass, ginger, and chili in a saucepan.
2. Simmer over medium heat until the mixture reduces to the consistency of a light syrup.
3. Season the sauce with salt and sugar.
4. Discard the chili and serve the sauce with the prepared salmon.

### CHAPTER 5
#### Fermenting Vegetables (and Some Fruits Too)

There is an underlying unity to all vegetable fermentation: By keeping vegetables submerged under liquid, you create a selective environment where molds and other oxygen-dependent organisms cannot grow, thereby encouraging acidifying bacteria. Beyond this simple technique, in all the particulars of what, where, when, and how, approaches to vegetable fermentation can be quite varied and quirky. Some traditions wilt vegetables, either in saltwater brine or in the sun; others pound or bruise fresh vegetables. Some people ferment a single vegetable, while others mix a dozen different vegetables together, perhaps along with spices, fruit, fish, rice, mashed potatoes, or other additions. Some people ferment theirs for just a few days; others for weeks, months, or even years. Some ferment in sealed jars; others in open crocks; others in specially designed vessels. Some ferment in cellars or buried crocks; others on balconies or in garages; still others right on their kitchen counters. Some ferment in the protection of darkness; others directly in the sun. Most traditions work with the bacteria native to the vegetables; some add various starters. There is no single way of accomplishing this task that has been so widely adopted.

   - Made by fermenting the sap of the agave plant, also known as the century plant or maguey.
   - The fermentable sap, referred to as *aguamiel* (honey water), is extracted from the agave.
   - The pulque production begins after nearly a decade of the plant maturing.

The document provided is a recipe for "Torrentés Peruvian Seafood Chowder," from a chef or establishment named Michelle Bernstein at Michy’s and Sra. Martinez in Miami, Florida.

### Recipe details:

**Makes**:
- 4 to 6 main-course servings

**Ingredients**:
- **Shrimp**: 2 pounds extra-large shrimp in the shell (about 24)
- **For Shrimp Stock**:
  - 1 tablespoon olive oil
  - Reserved shrimp shells
  - 3 cups water
  - 1 cup dry white wine
  - 2 bay leaves
  - 3 or 4 black peppercorns
- **For Chowder**:
  - 6 tablespoons olive oil
  - ½ cup finely chopped red onion
  - ¼ cup finely chopped red bell pepper
  - ¼ cup finely chopped fennel
  - 3 cloves garlic, minced
  - ⅓ teaspoon minced habanero or Scotch Bonnet chile
  - 1 cup dry white wine
  - ½ cup evaporated milk
  - Salt and freshly ground black pepper
  - ½ cup corn kernels (from about 1 ear)
  - ½ cup finely diced, peeled sweet potato
  - ¼ cup finely diced tomato with juice
  - ¼ cup finely chopped fresh cilantro leaves and stems
  - 4 large eggs, at room temperature, lightly beaten

**Instructions**:
1. Peel and devein the shrimp, reserving the shells. Refrigerate the shrimp until needed.
2. To make the stock, heat the olive oil in a heavy saucepan over medium-high heat until almost smoking. Add the shrimp shells and cook, stirring often, until deep red, 2 to 3 minutes. Add water, wine, bay leaves, and peppercorns and bring to a boil. Reduce the heat to medium-low and simmer gently for about 20 minutes to extract flavor.
3. Strain the stock through a fine-mesh sieve, pressing down on the shells with the back of a spoon to extract as much flavor as possible. Adjust volume to make 4 cups.

```markdown
# Kaiserschmarrn aux fruits rouges et chantilly coco

## Pour 4 personnes

### Temps de préparation: 20 minutes
### Temps de cuisson: 10 minutes
### Temps de réfrigération: 3 heures

## Ingrédients

- 300 g de fruits rouges (framboises, myrtilles, cassis, groseilles...) de votre choix, frais ou surgelés selon la saison
- 3 gros œufs ou issus de poules élevées en plein air
- 170 g de farine
- 30 g de sucre blond de canne
- 1 cuillère à café de bicarbonate de sodium
- 25 cl de lait entier (vache ou soja)
- 40 g de beurre

### Chantilly coco
- 1 bouteille de 40 cl de lait de coco
- ½ gousse de vanille

### Ustensile
- Batteur électrique

### Renvoi technique
- Voir page 127 pour "Prépare une chantilly de noix de coco"

## Instructions

### Pour la chantilly coco
1. Placez la bouteille de lait de coco au moins 3 heures au réfrigérateur.
2. Ouvrez-la et à l'aide d'une cuillère récupérez la couche supérieure de crème dense.
3. Mélangez la crème de coco obtenue dans un petit saladier avec les graines grattées de la gousse de vanille et réservez au réfrigérateur.

### Pour le kaiserschmarrn
1. Décongelez les fruits rouges si vous utilisez des fruits surgelés. Égouttez-les et séchez-les bien.
2. Séparez les blancs des jaunes d’œufs.
3. Mélangez la farine avec la cassonade et le bicarbonate. Ajoutez le lait et les jaunes d’œufs et mélangez à l'aide d'un fouet.
4. Montez les blancs en neige avec une pincée de sel. Ajoutez-les délicatement à la pâte avec les fruits rouges.
5. Faites fondre le beurre à feu moyen dans une grande poêle. Versez délicatement la pâte dans la poêle et laissez cuire 7 à 8 minutes, jusqu'à ce que la crêpe soit cuite en-dessous. À l'aide d'une spatule en bois, découpez grossièrement la crêpe en lanières et retournez les morceaux ainsi obtenus. Faites-les dorer 2 à 3 minutes.

### Pour finir
1. Fouettez la crème de coco en chantilly à l'aide d'un batteur électrique.
2. Saupoudrez le Kaiserschmarrn de la cassonade restante et servez sans attendre avec la chantilly.

## Le conseil du chef
Le lait de coco permet d'obtenir une chantilly sans lactose particulièrement savoureuse. Veillez à ne prélever que la partie crémeuse et à mettre de côté le lait de coco. Vous vous en servirez dans un smoothie ou dans une marinade.

## Bon à savoir
Le nom de cette spécialité autrichienne pourrait se traduire par « mélange (de l'Empereur) ». En effet, il est dit que l'archiduchesse Elisabeth (familièrement Sisi) aurait surpris Franz qui profitait d'un simple dessert en s'invitant à sa table. Très impressionnée, elle aurait raté son dessert improvisé avec les moyens du bord et l'aurait proposé directement dans la poêle, n'arrivant pas à le démouler. Une réalité ou une légende, l'Empereur aurait refoulé à l'origine garni de raisins secs et de compote de prunes ou de pommes, et il se décline désormais à toutes sortes de fruits.
```

### Text content from the document "Sugar Candies and Confectionery":

---

**How Sugar Crystals Form**
Sugar molecules have a natural tendency to bond to each other in orderly arrays and form dense solid masses, or crystals. When sugar crystals are dissolved in water to make a syrup, the water molecules overcome that tendency by forming their own bonds with the sugar molecules, surrounding and separating them from each other. If the dissolved sugar molecules in a syrup get too crowded for the water molecules to keep the sugars apart from each other, the sugars will begin to bond to each other again and form crystals.

**When Sugar Becomes Supersaturated**
When the syrup contains high levels of dissolved sugar and is then cooled, it can temporarily hold more sugar in solution than it could at normal temperatures, becoming supersaturated. This occurs because the cooling process reduces the sugar's mobility, making it less likely to spontaneously form crystals despite the solution’s high sugar concentration.

**Seed Crystals and Growth**
After a syrup becomes supersaturated, any minor disturbance can cause seed crystals to form, rapidly growing into larger sugar crystals. If these crystals are left undisturbed, they can lead to the formation of large, monolithic sugar masses.

**Candy Texture and Crystal Size**
When making candy, controlling the formation of sugar crystals is essential. Quick cooling or minimal disturbance can promote smaller, more homogenous crystal formation, resulting in a smooth, fine-textured candy. Slower cooling or disturbances can cause larger, discrete crystal formations, producing candy with a coarse texture.

**Degrees of Saturation:**
1. **Saturated:** The dissolved sugars are at equilibrium with their ability to dissolve further, typically achieved at higher temperatures.
2. **Supersaturated:** Contains more dissolved sugars than can normally be dissolved at a given temperature, frequently induced by rapidly cooling a hot, saturated sugar solution.

**Crystal Growth and Candy Texture**
Depending on how a syrup is managed after reaching a supersaturated state, the resultant candy's texture can vary:
- **Fine texture:** Achieved by fast cooling, which prevents the formation of large crystals.
- **Coarse texture:** Results from slower cooling or disturbances, allowing large crystals to form.

- **Lavender (Lavandula spp.)**: A Mediterranean plant valued for its floral-woody perfume. Although used more in soaps and candles, its dried blossoms are also a culinary ingredient especially in mixtures like herbes de provence.

- **Lemon Balm (Melissa officinalis)**: An Old World species known for its aroma derived from citronellal and citral, typically paired with fruit dishes and sweets.
  
- **Marjoram (Origanum majorana)**: Once classified close to oregano but noted for its less forceful flavor and more floral notes, making it a preferred component in many herb blends for dishes.

- **Mints**: Identified as mostly small plants from damp habitats in Europe, contributing to various culinary preparations.

---

**AN ANCIENT INGREDIENT**
Because fermented plant juices naturally turn sour with acetic acid, our ancestors discovered wine and vinegar together. In fact, a major challenge in winemaking was to delay this souring by limiting the wine’s exposure to the air. The Babylonians were making vinegar from date wine, raisin wine, and beer around 4000 BCE. They flavored their vinegar with herbs and spices, used it to pickle vegetables and meats, and added it to water to make it safe to drink. The Romans mixed vinegar and water to make an ordinary drink called *posca*, pickled vegetables in vinegar and brine, and judged by the late Roman recipe book of Apicius, often enjoyed vinegar in combination with honey. Pliny said that “no other sauce serves so well to season food or to heighten a flavor.” In the Philippines there developed a tradition of serving a variety of uncooked fish, meats, and vegetables in vinegar made from palm sap and tropical fruits. And the Chinese evolved dark, complex vinegars from rice, wheat, and other grains, which are sometimes roasted before fermentation.

For millennia, vinegar was made simply by allowing partly filled containers of wine and other alcoholic liquids to sour, an unpredictable process that took weeks or months. The first system for more rapid production, a bed of grapevine twigs over which the wine was regularly poured to aerate it, was invented in France in the 17th century. In the 18th century, Hermann Boerhaave, introduced the continuous trickling of wine over an aerating bed.

**THE VIRTUES OF ACETIC ACID**
Acetic acid contributes two different flavor elements to foods. One is its acidity on the tongue, and the other is its characteristic aroma in the nose, which can intensify to a kind of startling pungency, particularly when the vinegar is heated. The vinegar molecule can exist in two forms: as the intact molecule, and broken into its main portion and a free hydrogen ion. The hydrogen ion gives the main impression of acidity, while only the intact molecule is volatile and can escape from the vinegar or food, travel through the air, and reach the nose. Both the intact and “dissociated” forms coexist side by side, in proportions that are determined by their chemical surroundings. If the food is already acidic—thanks to the presence of tartaric acid in wine vinegar, for example—then less of the acetic acid dissociates, more is intact and volatile, and the vinegar aroma is stronger.

Acetic acid is an especially effective preserving agent. A solution as weak as 0.1%—the equivalent of a teaspoon of standard-strength vinegar in a cup of water/5 ml in 250 ml—will inhibit the growth of many microbes. Acetic acid has a higher boiling point.

**FOOD WORDS: VINEGAR, ACID, ACETIC**
Though it doesn’t look or sound related, the word *vinegar* comes from the same root as both *acid* and *acetic*: the Indo-European *ak-*, meaning “sharp.” (The agire in unaiagre was originally the Latin acer.) Edge, acute, acrid, ester, and oxygen are related words, oxygen because its presence was once thought necessary to make an acid.

# German Wine Laws and Labels

The vast majority of wine produced in Germany is PDO, and this will be the focus here. Some PGI wines are made and they are labelled Landwein. Wine without a GI is simply labelled Deutscher Wein.

For PDO wine, there are 13 delimited regions, some of which are covered in this chapter. However, these regions are not linked to specific grape varieties as is the case in the widely copied French appellation system. Instead, wines are typically varietally labelled and classified by minimum must weight at harvest. There are two fundamental levels in the system, Qualitätswein and Prädikatswein, and the latter is subdivided into six Prädikat categories. Each Prädikat can be made in a variety of different sweetness levels. The key information is shown in the table.

## Wine Labels

All PDO wines must come from only one region and the name of the region will appear on the label. For Prädikatsweine, the Prädikat level will also appear on the label. Varietal labelling is common and labels may also include information about the following three areas:

- **Sweetness** – Dry wines can be labelled trocken and wines that are off-dry or medium can be labelled halbtrocken. Some producers feel that halbtrocken has a negative association with lower quality wines and use the term feinherb instead. Unlike the other two terms, feinherb is not legally defined. Many wines do not have any indication of sweetness on the label but this can often be deduced from either the wine category or the alcohol level.
  
- **Vineyard Location** – This is commonly stated on German wine labels. The name of the village comes first and this is followed by the name of the vineyard. For example, a wine labelled Piesporter Goldtröpfchen is from the vineyard of Goldtröpfchen located in the village of Piesport. The vast majority of the wines labelled this way will be from small single vineyards. However, lower quality wines that are made from grapes that come from a large number of neighbouring vineyards can be labelled in the same way (for example, Piesporter Michelsberg).

## Table: Categories of PDO Wine and Wine Styles

| Minimum must weight at harvest | Category of PDO wine  | Wine Style         |
|--------------------------------|-----------------------|--------------------|
| lowest                         | Qualitätswein         | dry to medium sweet|
|                                | Prädikatswein:        |                    |
|                                | - Kabinett            | dry to medium sweet|
|                                | - Spätlese            | dry to medium sweet|
|                                | - Auslese             | dry to sweet       |
|                                | - Beerenauslese (BA)  | sweet only         |
|                                | - Eiswein             | sweet only         |
| highest                        | - Trockenbeerenauslese (TBA) | sweet only |

## Indications of Quality

- **The Prädikat levels** are a good indicator of style, something discussed in the section Riesling. However, there are no legally defined labelling terms, such as Premier Cru and Grand Cru, that can be used to indicate the quality level of a wine.
  
This has to some extent been addressed by an independent group of German wine producers called the Verband Deutscher Prädikatsweingüter (VDP). The members have classified their vineyards which, by consensus, include the vast majority of the best sites in Germany.

This classification is typically only seen on labels when members make dry Qualitätsweine from the best vineyard sites. These dry wines are called Grosses Gewächs and this is indicated by the letters GG and a bunch of grapes that are embossed on the neck of the bottle. The varieties permitted by the VDP vary from region to region. It is important to note that Grosses Gewächs is a trademark of the VDP and is not part of the German wine law. Nevertheless, these are considered to be the very best dry wines made in Germany.

### Goats' Cheese Textual Content Analysis

#### Main Points:
- **Flavor Profile**: Goats’ cheese is described as having a sharper, more pronounced flavor than cheese made from cow’s milk. This distinct flavor mainly originates from approximately half of the volatile compounds in goats’ milk, which are derived from the diet of the goats, consisting of fresh goats’ milk from the ruminant’s diet.
- **Diet Influence**: The diet of goats includes hay, alfalfa, grasses, and grains. This varied diet contributes to a more varied diet than dairy cows, influencing the unique flavor profile of goats’ cheese.
- **Chemical Composition**: Several compounds such as hexanal, (E)-2-nonenal, and decadienals contribute to the grassy, cucumber-like fragrance, and flavors like peach and coconut.
- **Aging Impact**: Fresh goats' cheese has a more delicate flavor than aged cheeses. Factors such as water-soluble compounds and fatty acids influence the flavor, with their effects becoming more pronounced as the cheese ages.

#### Graphs Analysis and Interpretation:

##### Graph 1: Flavor Profile of Goats' Milk (Unpasteurized)
- **Structure**: A circular graph divided into sections labeled ‘cheesy’, ‘fatty’. 
- **Contents**: The graph visually describes the dominating flavors like cheesy and fatty which are prominent in unpasteurized goats' milk.

##### Graph 2: Flavor Profile of Pasteurized Goats' Milk
- **Structure**: A circular graph divided into sections with a distinct comparison showing the reduction of ‘cheesy’ and ‘fatty’ flavors replaced by other mild flavors.
- **Contents**: Indicates that pasteurization leads to a decrease in the strong animal-like and fatty flavors, highlighting the introduction or emphasis on other flavors like rosemary honey, blackberry, and cinnamon.

#### Related Aroma Profiles
This section compares the flavor profiles of unpasteurized vs pasteurized goats' milk, particularly noting how pasteurization changes the flavor profile, reducing the robust animal-like odors.

#### Taste Profile of Goats' Milk vs Other Foods (Aromatic Compounds Intensity)
- **Description**: Two extensive grids showing the comparison of flavor intensities between goats' milk and other food items such as dry-cured ham, oyster leaf, and licorice.
- **Purpose**: Display the intensity of flavor/aroma compounds in goats’ milk compared to other specific foods, categorized by different sensory properties like woody, floral, peppery.

This structured content delineates the sensory profile of goats' cheese, influential dietary components, and the impact of pasteurization on flavor while comparing these qualities with various other foods quantitatively through aromatic intensity charts.

The document appears to be about fermentation and the making of beverages like kefir and root beer. Here's the content structured and summarized in plain text:

### Kefir Fermentation
- When fermenting kefir, the milk typically does not curdle immediately but does after two or three days. 
- Milk fats rise to the top before sinking. 
- It's suggested to shake the kefir jar to mix the curds and whey.
- For a stronger fermentation starter, use the whey when it's freshly fermented. 
- Whey can be stored in the refrigerator for weeks or months.

### Fermenting with Whey
- To ferment a beverage using whey, add whey to the base beverage at a proportion of about 5 to 10 percent volume-wise.
- For a quart or liter, this equates to roughly 2 to 3 ounces (¼ cup) or 50 to 100 ml of whey.
- The base beverage can be sweetened water, a sweetened herbal infusion, or fruit juice.
- Mix the whey into the chosen sweet liquid, ferment for about 24 hours until bubbly, then bottle and seal.
- The sealed bottles should remain at room temperature for another 24 hours or more until pressurized before refrigeration.
- Caution is advised to avoid excess pressure and potential explosions.

### Roots Beer
- Root beer is typically a sweetened and fermented beverage made from various plant roots.
- Contrary to common belief, the term “root” beer can involve a mixture of different roots, which enhances the flavor compared to using a single type of root.
- An example includes a mix of different roots in a plural root beer encountered in Jamaica as noted by someone named Frank Cook, emphasizing the diversity possible in root beer formulations.

This document provides practical tips on handling and fermenting beverages, emphasizing the flexibility and variations possible in traditional recipes.

Sure, here's the structured content of the provided document, "The History of Sauces in Europe":

---

**Stagnation in the 17th Century**
- **Claudio Benporat** asserted that culinary stagnation occurred due to a lack of strong Italian leadership and European influence.
- Italian courts focused on domestic and simple recipes, highlighting combinations of unrefined materials rather than extracting essences.

**Distinctive Techniques**
- **Italian** techniques involved cooking down materials like tomato fruits and basil leaves to create a concentrated flavor.
- The process involved cooking and browning meat to dissolve concentrated residues, then repeating to enhance flavors.

**Sauces in England: Gravies and Condiments**
- Historically, England was noted for its simplicity in sauces, contrasting with French cuisine.
- **Domenico Caraccioli** mentioned that England had few sauce recipes, often relying on basic additions like melted butter.
- Sauces such as anchovy, oyster, parsley, egg, caper, and others became popular in the 19th century.

**Culinary Standards in England**
- Unlike French cuisine which focuses on extravagant sauces, English cuisine incorporated sauces like Worcestershire and ketchups.
- **Hannah Glasse**, a popular English cook, emphasized practical recipes that required more meat and were less expensive.

**Influence of the East India Company**
- The commercial actions of the East India Company introduced richly flavored imports like kecap and pickled fruits and vegetables.
- These imports led to intensified and rich flavors in English cooking, influencing traditional recipes.

**Cultural Observations**
- **Doctor Johnson** described a sauce's purpose as enhancing food flavor, reflecting a more pragmatic English culinary perspective.
- This approach indicates a cultural difference in flavor appreciation between English and other European cuisines.

**Summary**
- The document discusses the development and cultural significance of sauces in European culinary history, particularly focusing on the differences between Italian, French, and English approaches to sauce-making.

### Cocktails Made by Bordeaux

#### Bordeaux Impérial
- **Ingredients**:
  - 3 large strawberries, chopped
  - 1 cl peach-apricot syrup
  - 3 cl white Bordeaux wine
  - A dash of gin
  - Bordeaux Crémant to top up
- **Method**:
  - Place strawberries and syrup in a shaker.
  - Add the white Bordeaux wine and gin.
  - Shake and strain into a glass.
  - Top up with Bordeaux Crémant.
- **Tip**: Prepare the mix in advance and keep it cool; serve with Crémant de Bordeaux at the last moment to impress your friends.

#### Bordeaux Zest
- **Ingredients**:
  - Half a lime, chopped
  - 1 spoon of cassonade (brown sugar)
  - 2 cl litchi syrup
  - Dry white Bordeaux wine to fill up (6-7 cl max)
- **Method**:
  - Crush the lime pieces with the sugar.
  - Add litchi syrup.
  - Fill with ice cubes and add white Bordeaux wine.
  - Stir well and serve with a straw.
- **Tip**: Work the lime and cassonade to release maximum lime zest flavors. Use a fruity, dry white Bordeaux.

#### Cosmo Bordeaux
- **Ingredients**:
  - 5 cl clairet (a type of light red wine or dark rosé)
  - 1 cl dry triple sec
  - 1 cl cranberry juice
  - A quarter of a lime
- **Method**:
  - Combine all ingredients in a shaker.
  - Shake and strain into a cocktail glass over ice.
- **Tip**: Use either Bordeaux Clairet or a fruity Bordeaux Rosé.

#### Bordeaux Rubis
- **Ingredients**:
  - A bunch of de-stemmed mint leaves
  - 4 raspberries
  - 2 cl red fruit cream
  - Dry red Bordeaux wine to top up (6-7 cl max)
- **Method**:
  - Work together mint and raspberries.
  - Add red fruit cream.
  - Fill with crushed ice up to three-quarters of the glass and top up with red Bordeaux wine.
- **Tip**: Do not shred the mint leaves to preserve their flavor.

This page not only introduces recipes but also offers practical tips for enhancing the cocktails with specific types of Bordeaux wines, adhering to the document's theme of showcasing the region's gastronomy through original drinks.

### Sweetness

The front of the tongue carries the buds to recognize the sweetness in the wine. Low acidity in wines means more sweetness and wines with higher acidity are less sweet. The pH (Potential of Hydrogen) factor defines the tartness of the taste of wine. An ideal wine is 2.6pH is ideal and 4.9 pH means the wine is flat. Average wines range between 3 and 4.9pH.

The document provided is a detailed exposition on milk and dairy products, particularly focusing on foams, Indian varieties of cooked milks, and their unique attributes. Below, the content is structured into three main sections, as outlined in the text:

### 1. Caramelizing Sweetened Condensed Milk
- **Topic Addressed:** Boiling sweetened condensed milk for a caramel sauce.
- **Key Info:** It involves heating in a can until caramelized, which although popular, contains risks due to trapped air expanding and potentially bursting.

### 2. Milk Foams
- **Definition and Composition:** Foam consists of air bubbles in a liquid, made typically from egg whites, whipped cream, or milk.
- **Characteristics:**
  - **Egg White and Whipped Cream Foams:** Less fragile, can prevent skin formation, insulate drinks, and improve taste.
  - **Milk Foams:** More fragile and immediate use recommended.
- **Foaming Dynamics:**
  - Due to proteins in milk, which collect air, isolate it, and prevent destabilization.

### 3. Milks and Their Foams
- **Comparative Analysis:** 
  - Some milks are better suited for foaming due to their whey proteins and potential fat content adjustments.
  - Full-fat milks foam less easily due to their natural composition.
- **Tips for Foaming and Heating:** 
  - Optimal foaming occurs slightly before milk begins to sour.
  - Above 160°F/70°C milk proteins unfold making them unsuitable for stable foams.

### 4. India's Galaxy of Cooked Milks
- **Cultural and Historical Insight:**
  - India has a diverse range of cooked milk recipes including khoa and dishes based on thickened milk.
- **Popular Varieties:**
  - **Khoa:** Made by repeatedly boiling milk to reduce its moisture, contains high lactose and protein.
  - **Burfi:** Solid, fudge-like treat derived from khoa.
  - **Chhanna:** Basis for sweets like rasgolla and ras malai, derived from curdling milk and pressing the curds.
- **Key Attributes:** 
  - Indian milk sweets commonly rely on the textural changes and concentration of sugars through boiling or curdling.

## Pairing Pointers

### Marsanne goes well with:

- **Most seafood**—the richer the better. From a mild Cajun crayfish étouffée to simply broiled lobster, these dishes pair well with the rich texture of Marsanne without the flavors fighting too hard. With aged wines, think about richer cooking or saucing techniques that pick up on the nutty character of the wine—a fish en croûte (wrapped in pastry) or scallops in a brown-butter sauce, topped with toasted breadcrumbs.
  
- **Many rich first courses.** I could drink a bottle of Marsanne with a plate of hamachi sashimi almost any day of the week. The smooth and creamy texture and lightly nutty flavor of my favorite sushi fish is magic with Marsanne. A mild cheese soufflé or a cream of potato soup also works. Rich but mild is the key here.
  
- **Pastas and risottos with creamy sauce.** As pasta and rice are both blank canvases onto which we paint flavors, they are perfect backdrops to many Marsanne-based wines. A risotto of shrimp, peas, and lots of butter is lovely, as is a bowl of spaghetti served with chicken, lemon zest, olives, and a sauce of reduced chicken stock.
  
- **Rich vegetables.** I adore Marsanne (and Roussanne too) with most squash and squash-based dishes. A plate of butternut-squash ravioli and a bowl of pumpkin soup are great examples of dishes that pair well. And with sautéed plantains—yum!
  
- **Exotically spiced dishes.** Marsanne’s ripe-fruit character is a reasonably neutral backdrop; like many other aromatic white wines, it pairs nicely with curry powder, cinnamon, cumin, and mace, among other spices.

### Marsanne isn’t good with:

- **Very spicy dishes.** Hot spices increase your perception of alcohol, and Marsanne tends to be high in alcohol. Use a soft touch with your hot salsa, favorite chile sauce, or shaker of red pepper flakes. Don’t attempt to pair hot Asian cuisine with a rich Marsanne blend unless you enjoy heartburn.
  
- **Lighter preparations.** Given the full-bodied nature of this wine, it’s easy to squash and lose simple dishes behind its girth. It’s gentle, but still a giant.
  
- **Very smoky foods.** Marsanne can be overwhelmed by mesquite-grilled meats, slowly smoked chicken, or a smoked-salmon terrine. The wine may still work, but it will lose any nuance of harmony with the dish.
  
- **Very sharp dishes.** This warning may seem counterintuitive, as you might expect the dish’s acid to fill in the gaps in the wine, but it usually just takes out what’s left. Avoid sweet and sour treatments, acidic sauces and ingredients (vinaigrettes, eggplant, zucchini), and even ceviche, unless you have a reasonably tart example of the wine.

- **Fermentation Method**: Malolactic fermentation vs. no malolactic fermentation

It's sometimes used by California vintners with the technique of oak aging to enhance flavor, which can lead it to transform tastes perceived differently from its original character—often changing into a semblance of Chardonnay.

### Characteristics of Pinot Blanc
- **Texture and Flavor**: Classic unoaked Pinot Blanc is described as delicate, fresh, and clean. It's similar in taste to dry Riesling and unoaked Chardonnay, with occasional floral and citric flavors, sometimes exhibiting a smoother texture akin to those of Scottish or Indian ghee.
- **Aging**: It can age gracefully, but many prefer it in a youthful state.

### Pairing with Food
Pinot Blanc pairs well with simple, subtle flavors rather than complex or bold ones:
- **Common Origins**: Most Pinot Blanc in the U.S. comes from Alsace, Oregon, and California.
- **Food Examples**: Can balance well with:
  - Oysters or mild crawfish boil
  - Grilled trout with lemon butter
  - Dishes with KISS (keep it simple, stupid) principles
- **Suggested Pairings**:
  - Straightforward dishes such as chicken pâté, savory mousse (with seafood), and basic crab cakes with aioli.
  - Richer versions are suggested with:
    - Sauteed whole steamed fish (e.g., with ginger)
    - Deep-fried dishes (such as tempura)
    - Grilled brochettes of chicken or prawns
- **Sophisticated Dishes**: Works with richer tastes like sashimi or smoked salmon and adaptable with everyday dishes such as a BLT with seafood or macaroni and cheese.

### Additional Notes
- **Versatility**: Highlights the versatility and flexibility of Crémant d'Alsace as a sparkling wine, comparable with Spanish Cava and Italian Prosecco in that category but underrated.

This document provides a comprehensive look at Pinot Blanc, focusing on how it is made and how it can be beautifully paired with various food items to enhance dining experiences.

Here's the structured content of the document titled "TASTES THAT PULL":

---

### TASTES THAT PULL

Where the “push” tastes have a tendency to put their shoulder into it and push all taste forward, the “pull” tastes seek out underlying flavors and highlight them. Some ingredients, like cooked onions or lemon juice, pull broadly, bringing every flavor forward. Others, like cinnamon or tarragon, are experienced as aromas that help to focus and highlight particular tastes. This brings us conveniently to the subject of the nose and smell. Brillat-Savarin, who thought more (and more clearly) about taste than anyone before or since, wrote “smell and taste form a single sense, of which the mouth is the laboratory and the nose is the chimney; or to speak more exactly, of which one serves for the tasting of actual body, the other for the savoring of their gases.” Even though gas, as a term of culinary art, has fallen out of favor and, in fact, is downright indelicate, Brillat-Savarin had it exactly right. Without the nose, there is very little taste and there would certainly be no cuisine to speak of. Not every pull taste is sensed primarily in the nose, though. In fact, two of the most important ones are anchored on the palate.

#### Tangy

Tangy (often called sour) and its close cousin, the vinted taste of wine, are primarily experienced in the mouth rather than the nose. We say they pull rather than push because that is what it feels like. Think about it: when you have a lot of vinegar in something, the tongue feels as if it's contracting. Anyone who was ever puckered after biting into a tart lemon and then tasted a fried shrimp understands that the lemon feels as if it's pulling flavor out of the shrimp. In contrast to the push tastes, tangy ingredients never smooth out or round flavors: instead, they seem to brighten them and make them more distinct. If salt is the king of tastes, tangy is the queen, perhaps not the most faithful of queens, though: she partners up just as easily with sweet, hot, and just about every other taste with the possible exception of bitter.

#### Vinted
